guide.introduction:
You’ve got some eyeglasses, plastic frames, broken. On the internet you found a repair place. In two weeks you can get them fixed. But what if you can’t wait?

Follow along and fix your glasses at home — the only special tool you need is a commonly available small-gauge drill bit. If you’re willing to take a risk and trust in your skills, you can have your glasses fixed as soon as tomorrow!

Tips on gluing:

The secret to good gluing technique is the Three Cs:

  • Cleaning: Surfaces should be clean and dry with a matte texture. The glue needs a solid, clean surface with a little “tooth” to bond to.
  • Clamping: Hold the parts steady while the glue sets, or the bond will be weakened.
  • Curing: Give the glue time to set. If you strain the bond before it’s fully set, it will be weaker.

So, to sum up: Clean the joint well, clamp it firmly, and let the glue cure, and you’ll have good results.

Relevant parts
  • Eyeglass frames
  • Nail polish remover
  • Swabs
  • Cloth
  • Stir stick
  • Rubber bands
  • Glue
  • Thread
  • Tape
Tools
  • Drill
  • Drill bit
  • Knife
  • Needle
  • Sandpaper
  • Scraping tool

parts.notes: Wash and let dry before using.
Any brand that's cyanoacrylate and runny. Don't use gel.
in a color that matches your glasses. Put glue on a test strand to see what it'll look like - silk darkens, polyester doesn't change much.

steps.title: Sand and clean the repair area.

lines.text: Use sandpaper to de-gloss the area of the repair. Lightly sand the break and scrape it with your hard pointy thing, to remove any loose pieces and to make sure it’s solid.
lines.text_raw: Use sandpaper to de-gloss the area of the repair. Lightly sand the break and scrape it with your hard pointy thing, to remove any loose pieces and to make sure it’s solid.

lines.text: Use a swab and nail polish remover or rubbing alcohol to scrub the repair area. Get it clean.
lines.text_raw: Use a swab and nail polish remover or rubbing alcohol to scrub the repair area. Get it clean.

steps.title: Make a clamp, and clamp the glasses.

lines.text: Cut a piece of stir stick to fit between the temples of your glasses, with some wiggle room. (You’ll want some overlap of the broken ends of the bridge, so you can clamp them together firmly.) Wrap it in wax paper or soft cloth to protect  your lenses.
lines.text_raw: Cut a piece of stir stick to fit between the temples of your glasses, with some wiggle room. (You’ll want some overlap of the broken ends of the bridge, so you can clamp them together firmly.) Wrap it in wax paper or soft cloth to protect  your lenses.

lines.text: Double over a rubber band and slip it over one end of the stick, then slide the end of one half of your glasses under the rubber band. Repeat for the other half.
lines.text_raw: Double over a rubber band and slip it over one end of the stick, then slide the end of one half of your glasses under the rubber band. Repeat for the other half.

lines.text: Scoot the 2 halves together, being careful not to mar the lenses, until the break is lined up and held snugly together. Small voids between the 2 sides are OK as long as there are some firm points of contact and things are lined up well.
lines.text_raw: Scoot the 2 halves together, being careful not to mar the lenses, until the break is lined up and held snugly together. Small voids between the 2 sides are OK as long as there are some firm points of contact and things are lined up well.

lines.text: This is the heart of the repair. If you don’t make this joint good and solid, the entire repair is at risk.
lines.text_raw: This is the heart of the repair. If you don’t make this joint good and solid, the entire repair is at risk.

lines.text: Use enough glue so the joint is full, but don’t let any run out. Make sure there are no bubbles, voids, or gaps in the joint. Be neat. Gently roll the side of a cotton swab over the glue to absorb any excess; avoid moving the joint, and blot quickly before it gets tacky.
lines.text_raw: Use enough glue so the joint is full, but don’t let any run out. Make sure there are no bubbles, voids, or gaps in the joint. Be neat. Gently roll the side of a cotton swab over the glue to absorb any excess; avoid moving the joint, and blot quickly before it gets tacky.

lines.text: Gently set the glasses somewhere safe to cure for 1 hour. Keep kids and pets away.
lines.text_raw: Gently set the glasses somewhere safe to cure for 1 hour. Keep kids and pets away.

steps.title: Drill holes for the tension band.

lines.text: Lay the glasses on a soft cloth and drill a hole on each side of the core joint, from top to bottom. Use a hobby knife to dig out little pilot holes before drilling. Place them far enough apart that the repair has a pleasing elongated shape, but not too far apart, or the band might sag.
lines.text_raw: Lay the glasses on a soft cloth and drill a hole on each side of the core joint, from top to bottom. Use a hobby knife to dig out little pilot holes before drilling. Place them far enough apart that the repair has a pleasing elongated shape, but not too far apart, or the band might sag.

lines.text: Drill slowly and carefully. Don’t stress the core joint or drill holes in your fingers!
lines.text_raw: Drill slowly and carefully. Don’t stress the core joint or drill holes in your fingers!

lines.text: The tension band is just thread that matches your glasses wound around the core joint through the holes you just drilled. It gives the repair strength.
lines.text_raw: The tension band is just thread that matches your glasses wound around the core joint through the holes you just drilled. It gives the repair strength.

lines.text: Thread a fine needle with 4'–6' of thread. Tape the loose end to one side of the frame so that you can wrap snugly. Make your wraps snug and tidy. At the same time, be gentle and don’t stress the joint.
lines.text_raw: Thread a fine needle with 4'–6' of thread. Tape the loose end to one side of the frame so that you can wrap snugly. Make your wraps snug and tidy. At the same time, be gentle and don’t stress the joint.

lines.text: Sew as many wraps of thread as you can. When the needle won’t fit through anymore, you’re done — pass the thread across the top and tape it to the opposite side of the frame.
lines.text_raw: Sew as many wraps of thread as you can. When the needle won’t fit through anymore, you’re done — pass the thread across the top and tape it to the opposite side of the frame.

lines.text: Use glue to fill the drilled holes and soak the thread, making sure there are no air bubbles, then lightly blot with a swab. Let it cure 15 minutes, and then trim the ends, being careful not to nick the tension band.
lines.text_raw: Use glue to fill the drilled holes and soak the thread, making sure there are no air bubbles, then lightly blot with a swab. Let it cure 15 minutes, and then trim the ends, being careful not to nick the tension band.

steps.title: Wind and glue the first radial wrap.

lines.text: Tape one end of the thread above a lens, and wrap it carefully and completely across the bridge of the glasses. Tape the far end down to the frame, but don’t trim it. Neat little wraps, all smoothly aligned, are the ideal. A little crisscrossing is unavoidable, but aim to make the overall effect smooth.
lines.text_raw: Tape one end of the thread above a lens, and wrap it carefully and completely across the bridge of the glasses. Tape the far end down to the frame, but don’t trim it. Neat little wraps, all smoothly aligned, are the ideal. A little crisscrossing is unavoidable, but aim to make the overall effect smooth.

lines.text: Soak the wrap in glue, making sure it penetrates to the layers below, with no bubbles. Blot lightly and let cure 10 minutes.
lines.text_raw: Soak the wrap in glue, making sure it penetrates to the layers below, with no bubbles. Blot lightly and let cure 10 minutes.

lines.text: Untape the far end and neatly wind the reverse radial wrap, in the opposite direction. The point is to make the 2 wraps’ threads cross over each other to give the repair stiffness and strength.
lines.text_raw: Untape the far end and neatly wind the reverse radial wrap, in the opposite direction. The point is to make the 2 wraps’ threads cross over each other to give the repair stiffness and strength.

lines.text: Tape the loose end down and soak the final wrap in glue, as before. Let it cure 2 minutes and then trim the ends neatly.
lines.text_raw: Tape the loose end down and soak the final wrap in glue, as before. Let it cure 2 minutes and then trim the ends neatly.

lines.text: Set the glasses aside to cure for 24 hours. Skimping on cure time will weaken the repair.
lines.text_raw: Set the glasses aside to cure for 24 hours. Skimping on cure time will weaken the repair.

lines.text: Now your glasses are ready to wear. Enjoy!
lines.text_raw: Now your glasses are ready to wear. Enjoy!
